00025   class GeodesicLine;
00026 
00027   /**
00028    * \brief %Geodesic calculations
00029    *
00030 
00031    * The shortest path between two points on a ellipsoid at (\e lat1, \e lon1)
00032    * and (\e lat2, \e lon2) is called the geodesic.  Its length is \e s12 and
00033    * the geodesic from point 1 to point 2 has azimuths \e azi1 and \e azi2 at
00034    * the two end points.  (The azimuth is the heading measured clockwise from
00035    * north.  \e azi2 is the "forward" azimuth, i.e., the heading that takes you
00036    * beyond point 2 not back to point 1.)
00037    *
00038    * Given \e lat1, \e lon1, \e azi1, and \e s12, we can determine \e lat2, \e
00039    * lon2, and \e azi2.  This is the \e direct geodesic problem and its
00040    * solution is given by the function Geodesic::Direct.  (If \e s12 is
00041    * sufficiently large that the geodesic wraps more than halfway around the
00042    * earth, there will be another geodesic between the points with a smaller \e
00043    * s12.)
00044    *
00045    * Given \e lat1, \e lon1, \e lat2, and \e lon2, we can determine \e azi1, \e
00046    * azi2, and \e s12.  This is the \e inverse geodesic problem, whose solution
00047    * is given by Geodesic::Inverse.  Usually, the solution to the inverse
00048    * problem is unique.  In cases where there are muliple solutions (all with
00049    * the same \e s12, of course), all the solutions can be easily generated
00050    * once a particular solution is provided.
00051    *
00052    * The standard way of specifying the direct problem is the specify the
00053    * distance \e s12 to the second point.  However it is sometimes useful
00054    * instead to specify the the arc length \e a12 (in degrees) on the auxiliary
00055    * sphere.  This is a mathematical construct used in solving the geodesic
00056    * problems.  The solution of the direct problem in this form is provide by
00057    * Geodesic::ArcDirect.  An arc length in excess of 180<sup>o</sup> indicates
00058    * that the geodesic is not a shortest path.  In addition, the arc length
00059    * between an equatorial crossing and the next extremum of latitude for a
00060    * geodesic is 90<sup>o</sup>.
00061    *
00062    * This class can also calculate several other quantities related to
00063    * geodesics.  These are:
00064    * - <i>reduced length</i>.  If we fix the first point and increase \e azi1
00065    *   by \e dazi1 (radians), the the second point is displaced \e m12 \e dazi1
00066    *   in the direction \e azi2 + 90<sup>o</sup>.  The quantity \e m12 is
00067    *   called the "reduced length" and is symmetric under interchange of the
00068    *   two points.  On a curved surface the reduced length obeys a symmetry
00069    *   relation, \e m12 + \e m21 = 0.  On a flat surface, we have \e m12 = \e
00070    *   s12.  The ratio \e s12/\e m12 gives the azimuthal scale for an azimuthal
00071    *   equidistant projection.
00072    * - <i>geodesic scale</i>.  Consider a reference geodesic and a second
00073    *   geodesic parallel to this one at point 1 and separated by a small
00074    *   distance \e dt.  The separation of the two geodesics at point 2 is \e
00075    *   M12 \e dt where \e M12 is called the "geodesic scale".  \e M21 is
00076    *   defined similarly (with the geodesics being parallel at point 2).  On a
00077    *   flat surface, we have \e M12 = \e M21 = 1.  The quantity 1/\e M12 gives
00078    *   the scale of the Cassini-Soldner projection.
00079    * - <i>area</i>.  Consider the quadrilateral bounded by the following lines:
00080    *   the geodesic from point 1 to point 2, the meridian from point 2 to the
00081    *   equator, the equator from \e lon2 to \e lon1, the meridian from the
00082    *   equator to point 1.  The area of this quadrilateral is represented by \e
00083    *   S12 with a clockwise traversal of the perimeter counting as a positive
00084    *   area and it can be used to compute the area of any simple geodesic
00085    *   polygon.
00086    *
00087    * Overloaded versions of Geodesic::Direct, Geodesic::ArcDirect, and
00088    * Geodesic::Inverse allow these quantities to be returned.  In addition
00089    * there are general functions Geodesic::GenDirect, and Geodesic::GenInverse
00090    * which allow an arbitrary set of results to be computed.  The quantities \e
00091    * m12, \e M12, \e M21 which all specify the behavior of nearby geodesics
00092    * obey addition rules.  Let points 1, 2, and 3 all lie on a single geodesic,
00093    * then
00094    * - \e m13 = \e m12 \e M23 + \e m23 \e M21
00095    * - \e M13 = \e M12 \e M23 - (1 - \e M12 \e M21) \e m23 / \e m12
00096    * - \e M31 = \e M32 \e M21 - (1 - \e M23 \e M32) \e m12 / \e m23
00097    *
00098    * Additional functionality is provided by the GeodesicLine class, which
00099    * allows a sequence of points along a geodesic to be computed.
00100    *
00101    * The calculations are accurate to better than 15 nm.  See Sec. 9 of
00102    * <a href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.1215v1">arXiv:1102.1215v1</a>
00103    * for details.
00104    *
00105    * The algorithms are described in
00106    * - C. F. F. Karney,
00107    *   <a href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.1215v1">Geodesics
00108    *   on an ellipsoid of revolution</a>,
00109    *   Feb. 2011;
00110    *   preprint
00111    *   <a href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.1215v1">arXiv:1102.1215v1</a>.
00112    * .
00113    * For more information on geodesics see \ref geodesic.
00114    **********************************************************************/
00115

00124     static const int nC2_ = GEOD_ORD;
00125     static const int nA3_ = GEOD_ORD;
00126     static const int nA3x_ = nA3_;
00127     static const int nC3_ = GEOD_ORD;
00128     static const int nC3x_ = (nC3_ * (nC3_ - 1)) / 2;
00129     static const int nC4_ = GEOD_ORD;
00130     static const int nC4x_ = (nC4_ * (nC4_ + 1)) / 2;
00131     static const unsigned maxit_ = 50;

00139     enum captype {
00140       CAP_NONE = 0U,
00141       CAP_C1   = 1U<<0,
00142       CAP_C1p  = 1U<<1,
00143       CAP_C2   = 1U<<2,
00144       CAP_C3   = 1U<<3,
00145       CAP_C4   = 1U<<4,
00146       CAP_ALL  = 0x1FU,
00147       OUT_ALL  = 0x7F80U,
00148     };
00149 
00150     static real SinCosSeries(bool sinp,
00151                              real sinx, real cosx, const real c[], int n)
00152       throw();
00153     static inline real AngNormalize(real x) throw() {
00154       // Place angle in [-180, 180).  Assumes x is in [-540, 540).
00155       return x >= 180 ? x - 360 : (x < -180 ? x + 360 : x);
00156     }
00157     static inline real AngRound(real x) throw() {
00158       // The makes the smallest gap in x = 1/16 - nextafter(1/16, 0) = 1/2^57
00159       // for reals = 0.7 pm on the earth if x is an angle in degrees.  (This
00160       // is about 1000 times more resolution than we get with angles around 90
00161       // degrees.)  We use this to avoid having to deal with near singular
00162       // cases when x is non-zero but tiny (e.g., 1.0e-200).
00163       const real z = real(0.0625); // 1/16
00164       volatile real y = std::abs(x);
00165       // The compiler mustn't "simplify" z - (z - y) to y
00166       y = y < z ? z - (z - y) : y;
00167       return x < 0 ? -y : y;
00168     }
00169     static inline void SinCosNorm(real& sinx, real& cosx) throw() {
00170       real r = Math::hypot(sinx, cosx);
00171       sinx /= r;
00172       cosx /= r;
00173     }
00174     static real Astroid(real x, real y) throw();
00175 
00176     real _a, _f, _f1, _e2, _ep2, _n, _b, _c2, _etol2;
00177     real _A3x[nA3x_], _C3x[nC3x_], _C4x[nC4x_];

00215     /**
00216      * Bit masks for what calculations to do.  These masks do double duty.
00217      * They signify to the GeodesicLine::GeodesicLine constructor and to
00218      * Geodesic::Line what capabilities should be included in the GeodesicLine
00219      * object.  They also specify which results to return in the general
00220      * routines Geodesic::GenDirect and Geodesic::GenInverse routines.
00221      * GeodesicLine::mask is a duplication of this enum.
00222      **********************************************************************/
00223     enum mask {
00224       /**
00225        * No capabilities, no output.
00226        * @hideinitializer
00227        **********************************************************************/
00228       NONE          = 0U,
00229       /**
00230        * Calculate latitude \e lat2.  (It's not necessary to include this as a
00231        * capability to GeodesicLine because this is included by default.)
00232        * @hideinitializer
00233        **********************************************************************/
00234       LATITUDE      = 1U<<7  | CAP_NONE,
00235       /**
00236        * Calculate longitude \e lon2.
00237        * @hideinitializer
00238        **********************************************************************/
00239       LONGITUDE     = 1U<<8  | CAP_C3,
00240       /**
00241        * Calculate azimuths \e azi1 and \e azi2.  (It's not necessary to
00242        * include this as a capability to GeodesicLine because this is included
00243        * by default.)
00244        * @hideinitializer
00245        **********************************************************************/
00246       AZIMUTH       = 1U<<9  | CAP_NONE,
00247       /**
00248        * Calculate distance \e s12.
00249        * @hideinitializer
00250        **********************************************************************/
00251       DISTANCE      = 1U<<10 | CAP_C1,
00252       /**
00253        * Allow distance \e s12 to be used as input in the direct geodesic
00254        * problem.
00255        * @hideinitializer
00256        **********************************************************************/
00257       DISTANCE_IN   = 1U<<11 | CAP_C1 | CAP_C1p,
00258       /**
00259        * Calculate reduced length \e m12.
00260        * @hideinitializer
00261        **********************************************************************/
00262       REDUCEDLENGTH = 1U<<12 | CAP_C1 | CAP_C2,
00263       /**
00264        * Calculate geodesic scales \e M12 and \e M21.
00265        * @hideinitializer
00266        **********************************************************************/
00267       GEODESICSCALE = 1U<<13 | CAP_C1 | CAP_C2,
00268       /**
00269        * Calculate area \e S12.
00270        * @hideinitializer
00271        **********************************************************************/
00272       AREA          = 1U<<14 | CAP_C4,
00273       /**
00274        * All capabilities.  Calculate everything.
00275        * @hideinitializer
00276        **********************************************************************/
00277       ALL           = OUT_ALL| CAP_ALL,
00278     };
00279 
00280     /** \name Constructor
00281      **********************************************************************/
00282     ///@{
00283     /**
00284      * Constructor for a ellipsoid with
00285      *
00286      * @param[in] a equatorial radius (meters)
00287      * @param[in] f flattening of ellipsoid.  Setting \e f = 0 gives a sphere.
00288      *   Negative \e f gives a prolate ellipsoid.  If \e f > 1, set flattening
00289      *   to 1/\e f.
00290      *
00291      * An exception is thrown if either of the axes of the ellipsoid is
00292      * non-positive.
00293      **********************************************************************/
00294     Geodesic(real a, real f);
00295     ///@}
00296 
00297     /** \name Direct geodesic problem specified in terms of distance.
00298      **********************************************************************/
00299     ///@{
00300     /**
00301      * Perform the direct geodesic calculation where the length of the geodesic
00302      * is specify in terms of distance.
00303      *
00304      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00305      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00306      * @param[in] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00307      * @param[in] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters); it can be
00308      *   signed.
00309      * @param[out] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00310      * @param[out] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees).
00311      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 2 (degrees).
00312      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters).
00313      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00314      *   (dimensionless).
00315      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00316      *   (dimensionless).
00317      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>).
00318      * @return \e a12 arc length of between point 1 and point 2 (degrees).
00319      *
00320      * If either point is at a pole, the azimuth is defined by keeping the
00321      * longitude fixed and writing \e lat = 90 - \e eps or -90 + \e eps and
00322      * taking the limit \e eps -> 0 from above.  An arc length greater that 180
00323      * degrees signifies a geodesic which is not a shortest path.  (For a
00324      * prolate ellipsoid, an additional condition is necessary for a shortest
00325      * path: the longitudinal extent must not exceed of 180 degrees.)
00326      *
00327      * The following functions are overloaded versions of Geodesic::Direct
00328      * which omit some of the output parameters.  Note, however, that the arc
00329      * length is always computed and returned as the function value.
00330      **********************************************************************/
00331     Math::real Direct(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real s12,
00332                       real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2,
00333                       real& m12, real& M12, real& M21, real& S12)
00334       const throw() {
00335       real t;
00336       return GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, false, s12,
00337                        LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH |
00338                        REDUCEDLENGTH | GEODESICSCALE | AREA,
00339                        lat2, lon2, azi2, t, m12, M12, M21, S12);
00340     }
00341 
00342     /**
00343      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Direct.
00344      **********************************************************************/
00345     Math::real Direct(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real s12,
00346                       real& lat2, real& lon2)
00347       const throw() {
00348       real t;
00349       return GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, false, s12,
00350                        LATITUDE | LONGITUDE,
00351                        lat2, lon2, t, t, t, t, t, t);
00352     }
00353 
00354     /**
00355      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Direct.
00356      **********************************************************************/
00357     Math::real Direct(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real s12,
00358                       real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2)
00359       const throw() {
00360       real t;
00361       return GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, false, s12,
00362                        LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH,
00363                        lat2, lon2, azi2, t, t, t, t, t);
00364     }
00365 
00366     /**
00367      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Direct.
00368      **********************************************************************/
00369     Math::real Direct(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real s12,
00370                       real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2, real& m12)
00371       const throw() {
00372       real t;
00373       return GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, false, s12,
00374                        LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH | REDUCEDLENGTH,
00375                        lat2, lon2, azi2, t, m12, t, t, t);
00376     }

00378     /**
00379      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Direct.
00380      **********************************************************************/
00381     Math::real Direct(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real s12,
00382                       real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2,
00383                       real& M12, real& M21)
00384       const throw() {
00385       real t;
00386       return GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, false, s12,
00387                        LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH | GEODESICSCALE,
00388                        lat2, lon2, azi2, t, t, M12, M21, t);
00389     }
00390 
00391     /**
00392      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Direct.
00393      **********************************************************************/
00394     Math::real Direct(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real s12,
00395                       real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2,
00396                       real& m12, real& M12, real& M21)
00397       const throw() {
00398       real t;
00399       return GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, false, s12,
00400                        LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH |
00401                        REDUCEDLENGTH | GEODESICSCALE,
00402                        lat2, lon2, azi2, t, m12, M12, M21, t);
00403     }
00404     ///@}

00406     /** \name Direct geodesic problem specified in terms of arc length.
00407      **********************************************************************/
00408     ///@{
00409     /**
00410      * Perform the direct geodesic calculation where the length of the geodesic
00411      * is specify in terms of arc length.
00412      *
00413      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00414      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00415      * @param[in] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00416      * @param[in] a12 arc length between point 1 and point 2 (degrees); it can
00417      *   be signed.
00418      * @param[out] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00419      * @param[out] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees).
00420      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 2 (degrees).
00421      * @param[out] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters).
00422      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters).
00423      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00424      *   (dimensionless).
00425      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00426      *   (dimensionless).
00427      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>).
00428      *
00429      * If either point is at a pole, the azimuth is defined by keeping the
00430      * longitude fixed and writing \e lat = 90 - \e eps or -90 + \e eps and
00431      * taking the limit \e eps -> 0 from above.  An arc length greater that 180
00432      * degrees signifies a geodesic which is not a shortest path.  (For a
00433      * prolate ellipsoid, an additional condition is necessary for a shortest
00434      * path: the longitudinal extent must not exceed of 180 degrees.)
00435      *
00436      * The following functions are overloaded versions of Geodesic::Direct
00437      * which omit some of the output parameters.
00438      **********************************************************************/
00439     void ArcDirect(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real a12,
00440                    real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2, real& s12,
00441                    real& m12, real& M12, real& M21, real& S12)
00442       const throw() {
00443       GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, true, a12,
00444                 LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH | DISTANCE |
00445                 REDUCEDLENGTH | GEODESICSCALE | AREA,
00446                 lat2, lon2, azi2, s12, m12, M12, M21, S12);
00447     }
00448 
00449     /**
00450      * See the documentation for Geodesic::ArcDirect.
00451      **********************************************************************/
00452     void ArcDirect(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real a12,
00453                    real& lat2, real& lon2) const throw() {
00454       real t;
00455       GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, true, a12,
00456                 LATITUDE | LONGITUDE,
00457                 lat2, lon2, t, t, t, t, t, t);
00458     }

00483     /**
00484      * See the documentation for Geodesic::ArcDirect.

00486     void ArcDirect(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real a12,
00487                    real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2,
00488                    real& s12, real& m12) const throw() {
00489       real t;
00490       GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, true, a12,
00491                 LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH | DISTANCE |
00492                 REDUCEDLENGTH,
00493                 lat2, lon2, azi2, s12, m12, t, t, t);
00494     }
00495 
00496     /**
00497      * See the documentation for Geodesic::ArcDirect.
00498      **********************************************************************/
00499     void ArcDirect(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real a12,
00500                    real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2, real& s12,
00501                    real& M12, real& M21) const throw() {
00502       real t;
00503       GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, true, a12,
00504                 LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH | DISTANCE |
00505                 GEODESICSCALE,
00506                 lat2, lon2, azi2, s12, t, M12, M21, t);
00507     }
00508 
00509     /**
00510      * See the documentation for Geodesic::ArcDirect.
00511      **********************************************************************/
00512     void ArcDirect(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real a12,
00513                    real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2, real& s12,
00514                    real& m12, real& M12, real& M21) const throw() {
00515       real t;
00516       GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, true, a12,
00517                 LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH | DISTANCE |
00518                 REDUCEDLENGTH | GEODESICSCALE,
00519                 lat2, lon2, azi2, s12, m12, M12, M21, t);
00520     }
00521     ///@}
00522 
00523     /** \name General version of the direct geodesic solution.
00524      **********************************************************************/
00525     ///@{
00526 
00527     /**
00528      * The general direct geodesic calculation.  Geodesic::Direct and
00529      * Geodesic::ArcDirect are defined in terms of this function.
00530      *
00531      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00532      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00533      * @param[in] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00534      * @param[in] arcmode boolean flag determining the meaning of the second
00535      *   parameter.
00536      * @param[in] s12_a12 if \e arcmode is false, this is the distance between
00537      *   point 1 and point 2 (meters); otherwise it is the arc length between
00538      *   point 1 and point 2 (degrees); it can be signed.
00539      * @param[in] outmask a bitor'ed combination of Geodesic::mask values
00540      *   specifying which of the following parameters should be set.
00541      * @param[out] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00542      * @param[out] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees).
00543      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 2 (degrees).
00544      * @param[out] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters).
00545      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters).
00546      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00547      *   (dimensionless).
00548      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00549      *   (dimensionless).
00550      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>).
00551      * @return \e a12 arc length of between point 1 and point 2 (degrees).
00552      *
00553      * The Geodesic::mask values possible for \e outmask are
00554      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::LATITUDE for the latitude \e lat2.
00555      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::LONGITUDE for the latitude \e lon2.
00556      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::AZIMUTH for the latitude \e azi2.
00557      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::DISTANCE for the distance \e s12.
00558      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::REDUCEDLENGTH for the reduced length \e
00559      *   m12.
00560      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::GEODESICSCALE for the geodesic scales \e
00561      *   M12 and \e M21.
00562      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::AREA for the area \e S12.
00563      * .
00564      * The function value \e a12 is always computed and returned and this
00565      * equals \e s12_a12 is \e arcmode is true.  If \e outmask includes
00566      * Geodesic::DISTANCE and \e arcmode is false, then \e s12 = \e s12_a12.
00567      * It is not necessary to include Geodesic::DISTANCE_IN in \e outmask; this
00568      * is automatically included is \e arcmode is false.
00569      **********************************************************************/
00570     Math::real GenDirect(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1,
00571                          bool arcmode, real s12_a12, unsigned outmask,
00572                          real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2,
00573                          real& s12, real& m12, real& M12, real& M21,
00574                          real& S12) const throw();
00575     ///@}
00576 
00577     /** \name Inverse geodesic problem.
00578      **********************************************************************/
00579     ///@{
00580     /**
00581      * Perform the inverse geodesic calculation.
00582      *
00583      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00584      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00585      * @param[in] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00586      * @param[in] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees).
00587      * @param[out] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters).
00588      * @param[out] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00589      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00590      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters).
00591      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00592      *   (dimensionless).
00593      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00594      *   (dimensionless).
00595      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>).
00596      * @return \e a12 arc length of between point 1 and point 2 (degrees).
00597      *
00598      * If either point is at a pole, the azimuth is defined by keeping the
00599      * longitude fixed and writing \e lat = 90 - \e eps or -90 + \e eps and
00600      * taking the limit \e eps -> 0 from above.  If the routine fails to
00601      * converge, then all the requested outputs are set to Math::NaN().  (Test
00602      * for such results with Math::isnan.)  This is not expected to happen with
00603      * ellipsoidal models of the earth; please report all cases where this
00604      * occurs.
00605      *
00606      * The following functions are overloaded versions of Geodesic::Inverse
00607      * which omit some of the output parameters.  Note, however, that the arc
00608      * length is always computed and returned as the function value.
00609      **********************************************************************/
00610     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00611                        real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2, real& m12,
00612                        real& M12, real& M21, real& S12) const throw() {
00613       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00614                         DISTANCE | AZIMUTH |
00615                         REDUCEDLENGTH | GEODESICSCALE | AREA,
00616                         s12, azi1, azi2, m12, M12, M21, S12);
00617     }
00618 
00619     /**
00620      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Inverse.
00621      **********************************************************************/
00622     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00623                        real& s12) const throw() {
00624       real t;
00625       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00626                         DISTANCE,
00627                         s12, t, t, t, t, t, t);
00628     }
00629 
00630     /**
00631      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Inverse.
00632      **********************************************************************/
00633     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00634                        real& azi1, real& azi2) const throw() {
00635       real t;
00636       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00637                         AZIMUTH,
00638                         t, azi1, azi2, t, t, t, t);
00639     }
00640 
00641     /**
00642      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Inverse.
00643      **********************************************************************/
00644     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00645                        real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2)
00646       const throw() {
00647       real t;
00648       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00649                         DISTANCE | AZIMUTH,
00650                         s12, azi1, azi2, t, t, t, t);
00651     }
00652 
00653     /**
00654      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Inverse.
00655      **********************************************************************/
00656     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00657                        real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2, real& m12)
00658       const throw() {
00659       real t;
00660       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00661                         DISTANCE | AZIMUTH | REDUCEDLENGTH,
00662                         s12, azi1, azi2, m12, t, t, t);
00663     }
00664 
00665     /**
00666      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Inverse.
00667      **********************************************************************/
00668     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00669                        real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2,
00670                        real& M12, real& M21) const throw() {
00671       real t;
00672       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00673                         DISTANCE | AZIMUTH | GEODESICSCALE,
00674                         s12, azi1, azi2, t, M12, M21, t);
00675     }
00676 
00677     /**
00678      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Inverse.
00679      **********************************************************************/
00680     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00681                        real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2, real& m12,
00682                        real& M12, real& M21) const throw() {
00683       real t;
00684       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00685                         DISTANCE | AZIMUTH |
00686                         REDUCEDLENGTH | GEODESICSCALE,
00687                         s12, azi1, azi2, m12, M12, M21, t);
00688     }
00689     ///@}
00690 
00691     /** \name General version of inverse geodesic solution.
00692      **********************************************************************/
00693     ///@{
00694     /**
00695      * The general inverse geodesic calculation.  Geodesic::Inverse is defined
00696      * in terms of this function.
00697      *
00698      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00699      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00700      * @param[in] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00701      * @param[in] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees).
00702      * @param[in] outmask a bitor'ed combination of Geodesic::mask values
00703      *   specifying which of the following parameters should be set.
00704      * @param[out] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters).
00705      * @param[out] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00706      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00707      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters).
00708      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00709      *   (dimensionless).
00710      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00711      *   (dimensionless).
00712      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>).
00713      * @return \e a12 arc length of between point 1 and point 2 (degrees).
00714      *
00715      * The Geodesic::mask values possible for \e outmask are
00716      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::DISTANCE for the distance \e s12.
00717      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::AZIMUTH for the latitude \e azi2.
00718      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::REDUCEDLENGTH for the reduced length \e
00719      *   m12.
00720      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::GEODESICSCALE for the geodesic scales \e
00721      *   M12 and \e M21.
00722      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::AREA for the area \e S12.
00723      * .
00724      * The arc length is always computed and returned as the function value.
00725      **********************************************************************/
00726     Math::real GenInverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00727                           unsigned outmask,
00728                           real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2,
00729                           real& m12, real& M12, real& M21, real& S12)
00730       const throw();
00731     ///@}
00732 
00733     /** \name Interface to GeodesicLine.
00734      **********************************************************************/
00735     ///@{
00736 
00737     /**
00738      * Set up to do a series of ranges.
00739      *
00740      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00741      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00742      * @param[in] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00743      * @param[in] caps bitor'ed combination of Geodesic::mask values
00744      *   specifying the capabilities the GeodesicLine object should possess,
00745      *   i.e., which quantities can be returned in calls to
00746      *   GeodesicLib::Position.
00747      *
00748      * The Geodesic::mask values are
00749      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::LATITUDE for the latitude \e lat2; this is
00750      *   added automatically
00751      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::LONGITUDE for the latitude \e lon2
00752      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::AZIMUTH for the latitude \e azi2; this is
00753      *   added automatically
00754      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::DISTANCE for the distance \e s12
00755      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::REDUCEDLENGTH for the reduced length \e m12
00756      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::GEODESICSCALE for the geodesic scales \e M12
00757      *   and \e M21
00758      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::AREA for the area \e S12
00759      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::DISTANCE_IN permits the length of the
00760      *   geodesic to be given in terms of \e s12; without this capability the
00761      *   length can only be specified in terms of arc length.
00762      * .
00763      * The default value of \e caps is Geodesic::ALL which turns on all the
00764      * capabilities.
00765      *
00766      * If the point is at a pole, the azimuth is defined by keeping the \e lon1
00767      * fixed and writing \e lat1 = 90 - \e eps or -90 + \e eps and taking the
00768      * limit \e eps -> 0 from above.
00769      **********************************************************************/
00770     GeodesicLine Line(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, unsigned caps = ALL)
00771       const throw();
00772 
00773     ///@}
00774 
00775     /** \name Inspector functions.
00776      **********************************************************************/
00777     ///@{
00778 
00779     /**
00780      * @return \e a the equatorial radius of the ellipsoid (meters).  This is
00781      *   the value used in the constructor.
00782      **********************************************************************/
00783     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw() { return _a; }
00784 
00785     /**
00786      * @return \e f the  flattening of the ellipsoid.  This is the
00787      *   value used in the constructor.
00788      **********************************************************************/
00789     Math::real Flattening() const throw() { return _f; }
00790 
00791     /**
00792      * <b>DEPRECATED</b>
00793      * @return \e r the inverse flattening of the ellipsoid.
00794      **********************************************************************/
00795     Math::real InverseFlattening() const throw() { return 1/_f; }
00796 
00797     /**
00798      * @return total area of ellipsoid in meters<sup>2</sup>.  The area of a
00799      *   polygon encircling a pole can be found by adding
00800      *   Geodesic::EllipsoidArea()/2 to the sum of \e S12 for each side of the
00801      *   polygon.
00802      **********************************************************************/
00803     Math::real EllipsoidArea() const throw()
00804     { return 4 * Math::pi<real>() * _c2; }
00805     ///@}
00806 
00807     /**
00808      * A global instantiation of Geodesic with the parameters for the WGS84
00809      * ellipsoid.
00810      **********************************************************************/
00811     static const Geodesic WGS84;
00812 
00813   };
